title: Acute Cholangitis
diagnosis_topic: Ascending infection of the biliary tree secondary to obstruction
setup_script: A 60-year-old man presents with fever, jaundice, and right upper quadrant pain. He has a history of gallstones but no prior surgeries. How would you proceed with this patient?

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 95/55 mmHg, HR 118 bpm, RR 22/min, Temp 39 °C, SpO₂ 95%.
Icteric sclera, right upper quadrant tenderness; may have hypotension and confusion (Reynolds pentad).
WBC 18 K/µL, bilirubin 5 mg/dL, alkaline phosphatase 300 U/L, AST/ALT mildly elevated.
Dilated common bile duct with gallstones; gallbladder with stones but no wall thickening.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates aggressive IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics
If resident consults gastroenterology for emergent ERCP
dynamic_flow.reply: ERCP performed; bile duct decompressed and stone removed.
What operative approach would you perform to decompress the biliary tree? Please describe your operative steps.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident proceeds to operative decompression (e.g., choledochotomy, T-tube drainage, biliary bypass)
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient stabilizes postoperatively with improved hemodynamics.
Patient develops septic shock and multiple organ failure.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident discusses Charcot’s triad and Reynolds pentad
dynamic_flow.reply: Fever, jaundice, and RUQ pain; pentad adds hypotension and altered mental status.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident addresses timing of cholecystectomy
dynamic_flow.reply: Interval cholecystectomy performed after cholangitis resolves.
Standard laparoscopic cholecystectomy performed; intraoperative cholangiogram considered to confirm ductal clearance.
Monitor for post-ERCP pancreatitis; continue antibiotics until sepsis resolves.
Discuss lifestyle modifications and gallstone prevention.

critical_decision_points: Recognition of acute cholangitis using Charcot’s triad/Reynolds pentad
Initial resuscitation with fluids and antibiotics
Urgent biliary decompression (ERCP or alternative surgical methods)
Avoiding delay that leads to septic shock
Planning for interval cholecystectomy and patient counseling

rubric.resident_feedback_template: Strengths:You demonstrated strong diagnostic reasoning by recognizing acute cholangitis using Charcot’s triad and Reynolds pentad. You appropriately prioritized resuscitation and urgent biliary decompression. Communication of your management plan was structured and clear. Areas for Improvement:Consider discussing alternative decompression strategies more consistently (percutaneous drainage or surgical exploration) when ERCP is unavailable. Earlier anticipation of complications such as septic shock would further strengthen your clinical judgment.
